dlp.interpolation
Class Curve

java.lang.Object
  dlp.interpolation.Curve

public class Curve
extends java.lang.Object

Easy-to-use interpolation curves, in four varieties. Once a curve is created, call the start() method to begin the interpolation. While running, the interpolation can be reverse()'d. Once finished, the curve can be turned around with swapEndpoints(), or new endpoints can be set with setStartValue(float) and setTargetValue(float). Start the animation again with start(). If you just want to re-live old times, play the whole thing back with restart(). If you like to live dangerously, you can even change the endpoints while the curve is interpolating (note: not actually dangerous).

Curve

public Curve(processing.core.PApplet parent,
             float start,
             float target,
             int frames,
             int curve)
Create a curve from start to target, lasting for frame frames, with the indicated curve type.

Parameters:
parent - The host sketch object, typically "this" unless you're doing something crazy.
start - The initial value of the interpolation.
target - The final value of the interpolation.
frames - The number of frames that the interpolation will last.
curve - The type of interpolation curve (e.g. Curve.EASE_IN).
See Also:
LINEAR, EASE_IN, EASE_OUT, EASE_IN_OUT
Method Detail

pre

public void pre()

setStartValue

public void setStartValue(float value)
Set the initial value of the curve (i.e., the value when t = 0). If the curve is not currently interpolating, also reset() the interpolation.

Parameters:
value - The new initial value.

setTargetValue

public void setTargetValue(float value)
Set the target value of the curve (i.e., the value when t = 1). If the curve is not currently interpolating, also reset() the interpolation.

Parameters:
value - The new target value.

setDuration

public void setDuration(int frames)
Set the duration of the curve's interpolation, in frames. If the curve is not currently interpolating, also reset() the interpolation.

Parameters:
frames - The number of frames that the interpolation should last for.

start

public void start()
Start the curve's interpolation. Note that if the curve has finished, but its initial or target values have not been changed and it has not reversed, then this will do nothing. If you want to just rewind the curve and play it back from the beginning, use restart().

toggle

public void toggle()
Toggle the curve's interpolation. If the curve is not interpolating, it will start, and vice-versa. Does not reset or restart the interpolation. Think of this as a play/pause button.

reverse

public void reverse()
Reverse the direction of interpolation (whether t is increasing or decreasing). If the curve is currently interpolating, this will take effect immediately. If the curve has finished interpolating, you will need to start() it again.

Note that reversing a curve is not quite the same as swapping the endpoints, if the curve is not symmetric about the midpoint. For example, an ease-in curve starts out slowly and gets faster as time goes on; it is not symmetric about the midpoint, since it's going faster at t = 0.9 than at t = 0.1, even though both times are the same distance from t = 0.5. If you reverse this curve, then t = 0.9 near the beginning, rather than the end, of the interpolation. Since this is an ease-in curve, it will be going quickly at this point, but when t = 0.1 (near the end), it will be going slowly. Long story short, this reversed ease-in curve behaves as if it were an un-reversed ease-out curve with the endpoints swapped!

For an example which might make the above explanation clear, see the ReverseVsSwap.pde file in the examples directory.

See Also:
swapEndpoints()

swapEndpoints

public void swapEndpoints()
If the interpolation has finished, swap the start and target values, and reset the curve.

Note that, for some curves, this is not quite the same as reversing. See reverse() for a more thorough discussion.

reset

public void reset()
Stop the interpolation and reset it back to the beginning, but don't start it again.

restart

public void restart()
Restart the interpolation from the beginning. No matter the current state, the curve will be interpolating after calling this method.

value

public float value()
Get the current interpolation value of the curve.

Returns:
A float in the range [startValue, targetValue].

t

public float t()
Get the current time of the curve's interpolation.

Returns:
A float in the range [0, 1].

animating

public boolean animating()
Get whether or not the curve is currently interpolating.

Returns:
A boolean indicating if the curve is interpolating.

finished

public boolean finished()
Get whether or not the curve's interpolation has finished. Note that this is not quite the same as the negation of the return value of animating(), as this is true if and only if the interpolation has been started, allowed to run its course, and is currently stopped (i.e., has not had reset(), restart(), or reverse() called upon it since stopping). The upshot of this is you can create a curve without starting interpolation until some point down the road, and anything that's waiting for the curve to start and then finish interpolating can check for that condition with only this method.

Returns:
A boolean indicating if the curve's interpolation is finished.
